articles.headline: Supreme Court Vacancy Has Left and Right Ready to Pounce
articles.snippet: With the prospect of a nomination by President Obama, Washington’s liberal and conservative advocacy machines are roaring to life in record time.
articles.abstract: With the prospect of a nomination by President Obama, Washington’s liberal and conservative advocacy machines are roaring to life in record time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s senior adviser and his top lawyer were blunt with liberal activists on a strategy call as they jumped into what political professionals in Washington expect to be one of the hardest-fought Supreme Court battles in a generation.

articles.headline: Apple’s Stance Highlights a More Confrontational Tech Industry
articles.snippet: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over a terrorist’s cellphone is heading toward an eventual victory for tech companies.
articles.abstract: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over a terrorist’s cellphone is heading toward an eventual victory for tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over unlocking a terrorist’s smartphone is the culmination of a slow turning of the tables between the technology industry and the United States government.

articles.headline: Nikki Haley Endorses Marco Rubio, Aiming to Project Vibrant New G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Together, Mr. Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, and Ms. Haley, the daughter of Sikh immigrants from India, hope to form a powerful contrast to an older generation of Republicans who have long controlled the party.
articles.abstract: Together, Mr. Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, and Ms. Haley, the daughter of Sikh immigrants from India, hope to form a powerful contrast to an older generation of Republicans who have long controlled the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAPIN, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Wednesday won the coveted backing of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, bringing together two of the youngest Republican rising stars at a moment when their party is facing difficult questions about whether instead to look to its past or to political outsiders for leadership.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Blacks See Bias in Delay on a Scalia Successor
articles.snippet: Some African-Americans saw the move by Republicans to block a Supreme Court nomination as another attempt to deny the legitimacy of the Obama presidency.
articles.abstract: Some African-Americans saw the move by Republicans to block a Supreme Court nomination as another attempt to deny the legitimacy of the Obama presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — As he left Martha Lou’s Kitchen, a soul food institution here on Wednesday, Edward Gadsden expressed irritation about the Republican determination to block President Obama from selecting Justice Antonin Scalia’s replacement on the Supreme Court.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Apple Letter on iPhone Security Draws Muted Tech Industry Response
articles.snippet: A complicated set of factors influences the reactions of technology companies to government demands to unlock a path to customer data.
articles.abstract: A complicated set of factors influences the reactions of technology companies to government demands to unlock a path to customer data.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a federal court ordered Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by an attacker in a December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., the company’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, penned a passionate letter warning of far-reaching implications beyond the case.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Nigeria’s Booming Film Industry Redefines African Life
articles.snippet: Nollywood is resonating across the continent with its stories of a pre-colonial past and of a present caught between village life and urban modernity.
articles.abstract: Nollywood is resonating across the continent with its stories of a pre-colonial past and of a present caught between village life and urban modernity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASABA, Nigeria — Sitting on a blue plastic stool in the sweltering heat, Ugezu J. Ugezu, one of Nigeria’s top filmmakers, was furiously rewriting his script as the cameras prepared to roll. “Cut!” he shouted after wrapping up a key scene, a confrontation between the two leading characters. Then, under his breath, he added, “Good as it gets.”
